OK, a PermGenSpace issue normally indicates that it's out of the special area of memory that becomes full when there's too many strings (usually caused by lots of classes, but not always) that are loaded up.

Once you get these, it's game over. However, the launcher (in 3.3) has an argument that can be used to provide a default of (IIRC) 256m of PermGenSpace, rather than the default 64. That's only kicked in if it thinks the VM knows about it, which might indicate that this is not finding it. What's the header of the workspace/.metadata/.log file (the one that contains what the startup arguments were and what version of the VM it is?)

If you look at the eclipse.ini, you'll see something like:

--launcher.XXMaxPermSize ...

that might not be taking effect. At the bottom of your eclipse.ini, can you put (on separate lines)

-vmargs
-XX:PermSize=128m
-XX:MaxPermSize=256m

(you don't need to put the -vmargs again if it already exists)

What OS and JVM version are you using? Is it a 64-bit or open-source VM?

Alex.

That's odd. The 3.3 launcher changed a bit, but that looks like a 3.2 eclipse.ini file, as otherwise it would have the --launcher stuff in it.

The --launcher basically does a test to see if the PermGen VM args are understaood, and then appends them if they are (and doesn't otherwise). Putting -XX:PermGen on yourself at the bottom (i.e. after the -vmargs) will essentially have the same effect. So you only really need one or the other. If you're setting it up for distribution onto many machines with potentially different VMs, I'd advise the --launcher variant; but if you're doing this just for your desktop machine it basically makes no difference.

Alex.
